skill.name: comparative-matrix
skill.description: Generate structured comparisons and decision matrices across analyzed frameworks. Use when (1) comparing multiple frameworks or approaches side-by-side, (2) making architectural decisions between alternatives, (3) creating best-of-breed selection documentation, (4) synthesizing findings from multiple analysis skills into actionable decisions, or (5) producing recommendation reports for technical stakeholders.
skill.summary: Generate structured comparisons and decision matrices across analyzed frameworks. Use when (1) compa...
skill.author: Dowwie

security_audit.summary: This is a prompt-only skill containing only documentation and structured templates in markdown format. No executable code, network calls, filesystem access, or command execution capabilities detected.

content.value_statement: Technical teams struggle to compare multiple frameworks objectively when making architectural decisions. This skill synthesizes analysis outputs into structured decision matrices with clear recommendations and trade-off documentation.
actual_capabilities: Collects and normalizes analysis outputs from multiple frameworks
Generates comparison matrices across standardized dimensions
Applies decision heuristics based on scalability, DX, or production requirements
Documents recommendations with clear rationale and trade-offs
Produces structured output artifacts including summary tables and detailed analysis
limitations: Does not execute code or perform live framework testing
Requires input analysis from other skills to function effectively
Does not provide runtime performance benchmarks
Cannot access external documentation or APIs directly

use_cases.title: Evaluate architectural options
use_cases.description: Compare multiple agent frameworks when designing new systems with specific requirements for scalability and maintainability.

use_cases.title: Select best frameworks
use_cases.description: Create evidence-based recommendations for tool selection based on team skills, project constraints, and long-term maintainability.

use_cases.title: Document technical decisions
use_cases.description: Produce clear comparison documentation for stakeholders showing trade-offs and rationale behind framework selections.

prompt_templates.title: Basic Comparison
prompt_templates.prompt: Use comparative-matrix to compare [Framework A] and [Framework B] across these dimensions: typing approach, async model, state management, configuration style, and extensibility pattern.

prompt_templates.title: Multi-Framework Analysis
prompt_templates.prompt: Generate a best-of-breed matrix comparing [Framework A], [Framework B], and [Framework C] for [use case]. Focus on typing, async, state, config, and extensibility.

prompt_templates.title: Production Readiness
prompt_templates.prompt: Apply production-first heuristics to evaluate [framework] for mission-critical deployment. Document observability needs, error boundaries, and typing requirements.

prompt_templates.title: Team Fit Assessment
prompt_templates.prompt: Use DX-first heuristics to compare frameworks for a small team doing rapid iteration. Consider learning curve, configuration style, and code complexity.

output_examples.input: Compare LangChain and AutoGen for building multi-agent systems using comparative-matrix
output: Key dimensions compared: Reasoning Pattern, Multi-Agent Coordination, Memory Strategy, Observability, Tool Interface
Recommendation: [Framework] with rationale based on your specific requirements

best_practices: Provide detailed analysis outputs from other skills as input for richer comparisons
Specify your decision criteria (scalability, DX, or production priorities) upfront
Review the trade-off log to ensure all compromises are understood before deciding
anti_patterns: Using this skill without prior framework analysis as input
Skipping the trade-off documentation when making final decisions
Ignoring the decision heuristics that match your project requirements

faq.question: What inputs does this skill need?
faq.answer: Analysis outputs from other skills like architecture-synthesis or tool-interface-analysis work best as input data for comparisons.

faq.question: What frameworks can it compare?
faq.answer: Any software frameworks. The skill uses flexible dimensions like typing, async, state, config, and extensibility.

faq.question: Does it require network access?
faq.answer: No. This is a prompt-based skill that synthesizes text inputs without making external network calls.

faq.question: Is my data safe with this skill?
faq.answer: Yes. This skill only processes text locally within your AI conversation and does not store or transmit data externally.

faq.question: How many frameworks can it compare at once?
faq.answer: The skill handles any number of frameworks. More inputs create larger matrices but maintain the same comparison structure.

faq.question: How is this different from architecture-synthesis?
faq.answer: Comparative-matrix creates side-by-side framework comparisons. Architecture-synthesis designs new systems based on requirements.
